title: Lesson 14: Introduction to Uniform Circular Motion
content:
Lesson 14: Introduction to Uniform Circular Motion

Going in Circles, but Always Accelerating!

Imagine an athlete running around a circular track at a perfectly steady pace. Her speedometer never changes. Is she accelerating? The answer might surprise you and is key to understanding one of the most common types of motion in the universe!

1. What is Uniform Circular Motion?

Let's break down the name. It sounds complicated, but it's really simple:

  • U
    Uniform: This means "constant" or "unchanging." In this context, it refers to a constant speed. The object is not speeding up or slowing down.
  • C
    Circular: This simply means the path of the motion is a circle.
  • M
    Motion: The object is moving.

So, Uniform Circular Motion (UCM) is the movement of an object in a circular path at a constant speed.

2. The Big Idea: Speed is Constant, but Velocity is NOT!

This is the most important concept to understand. Remember the difference:

  • Speed is just a number (a scalar). It tells you "how fast." Example: 10 m/s.
  • Velocity is speed plus direction (a vector). It tells you "how fast and which way." Example: 10 m/s to the East.

As you can see, even though the length of the velocity arrow (representing speed) stays the same, its direction is constantly changing. It's always pointing tangent to the circle. Since velocity is changing, the object must be accelerating!

3. The Secret Acceleration

So, we've established that an object in UCM is always accelerating. But in which direction?

In uniform circular motion, the acceleration is always directed towards the center of the circle. This is called Centripetal Acceleration. The word "centripetal" means "center-seeking."

This acceleration is caused by a centripetal force. Think of a stone tied to a string. The tension in the string provides the force that constantly pulls the stone inward, keeping it from flying away in a straight line.

4. How to Calculate Speed in UCM

Since the speed is constant, we can calculate it using a simple formula based on distance and time. For one full circle:

  • The distance is the circumference of the circle, which is 2πr.
  • The time taken is called the time period, represented by T.

v = 2πr / T

v = speed (in m/s)

r = radius of the circle (in meters)

T = time period for one revolution (in seconds)

π ≈ 3.14

Example Problem:

An athlete completes one round of a circular track of radius 50 m in 100 seconds. Calculate her speed.

Given:

r = 50 m

T = 100 s

Formula:

v = 2πr / T

Calculation:

v = (2 × 3.14 × 50) / 100

v = 314 / 100

v = 3.14 m/s

Answer: The athlete's speed is 3.14 m/s.

Lesson Summary: Key Takeaways

  • Constant Speed: In UCM, the object's speed does not change.
  • Changing Velocity: The direction of motion is always changing, so the velocity is always changing.
  • Centripetal Acceleration: Because velocity changes, there is an acceleration that always points to the center of the circle.
  • Speed Formula: The speed can be calculated with v = 2πr / T.
questions:
Lesson 14: Uniform Circular Motion - Questions

1

Is an object moving in a circle at a constant speed accelerating? Explain your answer.

Yes, the object is accelerating. Here's why:

  • Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, not just speed.
  • Velocity is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude (speed) and direction.
  • In circular motion, the direction of the object is continuously changing at every point on the circle.
  • Since the direction of velocity is changing, the velocity itself is changing. Therefore, the object is accelerating.
2

The tip of a fan blade is moving in a circle. In which direction does its acceleration point?

The acceleration of an object in uniform circular motion always points towards the center of the circle.

This type of "center-seeking" acceleration is called centripetal acceleration.

3

A stone is being swung in a circle on a string. If the string breaks, which path will the stone follow?

The stone will follow Path B.

  • According to the law of inertia, an object in motion will stay in motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a force.
  • The string provides the inward (centripetal) force to keep the stone moving in a circle.
  • When the string breaks, this force disappears. The stone continues in the direction it was moving at that exact moment, which is tangent to the circle.
4

An athlete completes one round of a circular track of diameter 200 m in 40 s. What is his speed? (Use π = 3.14)

Step 1: Find the radius (r).

The diameter is 200 m, so the radius is half of that.

r = Diameter / 2 = 200 m / 2 = 100 m

Step 2: List the given values.
  • Radius (r) = 100 m.
  • Time for one round (T) = 40 s.
Step 3: Use the formula for speed in UCM.

v = 2πr / T

Step 4: Substitute the values and calculate.

v = (2 × 3.14 × 100) / 40

v = 628 / 40

v = 15.7 m/s

The athlete's speed is 15.7 m/s.

5

An artificial satellite is moving in a circular orbit of radius 42,250 km. Calculate its speed if it takes 24 hours to revolve around the earth. (Give the answer in km/h)

Step 1: List the given values.
  • Radius (r) = 42,250 km.
  • Time period (T) = 24 hours.
Step 2: Use the speed formula.

v = 2πr / T

Step 3: Calculate the speed. (Use π ≈ 3.14)

v = (2 × 3.14 × 42250 km) / 24 h

v = 265330 km / 24 h

v ≈ 11055.4 km/h

The speed of the satellite is approximately 11,055.4 km/h.

6

The tip of a clock's second hand is 7 cm long. What is the speed of the tip?

Step 1: Identify the hidden and given information.
  • The length of the hand is the radius (r) = 7 cm.
  • The second hand completes one full circle in 60 seconds, so the time period (T) = 60 s.
Step 2: Use the speed formula.

v = 2πr / T

Step 3: Calculate the speed. (Use π ≈ 22/7 for easier calculation)

v = (2 × (22/7) × 7 cm) / 60 s

v = (2 × 22 cm) / 60 s

v = 44 cm / 60 s

v ≈ 0.73 cm/s

The speed of the tip is approximately 0.73 cm/s.

7

A car moves on a circular road of radius 50 m at a constant speed. If it takes 25 seconds to complete one lap, what is its speed?

Step 1: List the given values.
  • Radius (r) = 50 m.
  • Time period (T) = 25 s.
Step 2: Use the speed formula.

v = 2πr / T

Step 3: Calculate the speed. (Use π ≈ 3.14)

v = (2 × 3.14 × 50 m) / 25 s

v = 314 m / 25 s

v = 12.56 m/s

The speed of the car is 12.56 m/s.

8

Is the motion of a simple pendulum an example of uniform circular motion? Why or why not?

No, it is not.

For motion to be uniform circular motion, the speed must be constant.

  • A pendulum's speed is fastest at the bottom of its swing.
  • It slows down as it rises, momentarily stopping at the highest point of its swing.
  • Since its speed is continuously changing, it is not uniform circular motion. (It is an example of oscillatory motion).
9

An object moves in a circular path. After completing one full circle, what is its displacement?

The displacement is zero.

  • Displacement is the shortest straight-line distance between the starting point and the final point.
  • After one full circle, the object returns to its exact starting point.
  • Therefore, the distance between the start and end points is zero.
10

A cyclist is moving at a speed of 10 m/s on a circular track of radius 31.8 m. How much time will they take to complete one lap? (Use π ≈ 3.14)

Step 1: List the given values.
  • Speed (v) = 10 m/s.
  • Radius (r) = 31.8 m.
Step 2: Rearrange the speed formula to solve for Time (T).

The original formula is: v = 2πr / T

By rearranging, we get: T = 2πr / v

Step 3: Substitute the values and calculate.

T = (2 × 3.14 × 31.8 m) / 10 m/s

T = 199.704 / 10

T ≈ 20 s

The cyclist will take approximately 20 seconds to complete one lap.
exercises:
Lesson 14: Uniform Circular Motion - Exercises

1

The Merry-Go-Round Race

Two friends, Priya and Rahul, are riding on a merry-go-round that completes one full rotation every 10 seconds. Priya is sitting near the edge, 5 meters from the center. Rahul is sitting closer to the middle, only 3 meters from the center. Who is moving with a greater speed? Calculate both their speeds.

Priya is moving with a greater speed. Here's the logic and calculation:

Both friends complete a rotation in the same time (T = 10s), but Priya, being on the edge, has to travel a much larger circle (larger distance) in that same amount of time.

Step 1: Calculate Priya's speed (r = 5 m).

v = 2πr / T = (2 × 3.14 × 5 m) / 10 s = 31.4 / 10 = 3.14 m/s

Step 2: Calculate Rahul's speed (r = 3 m).

v = 2πr / T = (2 × 3.14 × 3 m) / 10 s = 18.84 / 10 = 1.884 m/s

Conclusion: Priya's speed (3.14 m/s) is greater than Rahul's speed (1.884 m/s).

2

Fill in the Blanks

Complete the sentences below using the correct terms from the word bank.

Word Bank: speed, velocity, zero, center, tangent, accelerating
  1. In uniform circular motion, the is constant, but the is always changing.
  2. Because its velocity changes, an object in UCM is always .
  3. The acceleration vector always points towards the of the circle.
  4. After one complete revolution, the displacement of the object is .
Correct Answers:
  1. In uniform circular motion, the speed is constant, but the velocity is always changing.
  2. Because its velocity changes, an object in UCM is always accelerating.
  3. The acceleration vector always points towards the center of the circle.
  4. After one complete revolution, the displacement of the object is zero.
3

Half-Track Challenge

An athlete runs on a semi-circular track with a radius of 35 meters. She starts at point A and finishes at point B, taking 22 seconds. Calculate:

(a) The distance she covered.

(b) Her displacement.

(c) Her average speed.

(a) Distance Covered:

The distance is the length of the semi-circular path. The circumference of a full circle is 2πr, so for a semi-circle, it's half of that: πr.

Distance = π × r = (22/7) × 35 m = 22 × 5 = 110 m

(b) Displacement:

Displacement is the straight-line distance from start (A) to finish (B). This is simply the diameter of the circle.

Displacement = Diameter = 2 × r = 2 × 35 m = 70 m

(c) Average Speed:

Average speed is the total distance divided by the total time.

Speed = Total Distance / Time = 110 m / 22 s = 5 m/s

4

True or False Challenge

Read each statement carefully and decide if it is True or False.

  • 1. An object in UCM has a constant velocity. (True / False)
  • 2. If an object's speed is constant, its acceleration must be zero. (True / False)
  • 3. The distance and displacement are the same after one full circle. (True / False)
  • 4. An inward force is required to maintain circular motion. (True / False)
  1. False. The speed is constant, but the velocity is not because the direction is always changing.
  2. False. This is only true for straight-line motion. In circular motion, an object with constant speed is still accelerating (centripetal acceleration).
  3. False. The distance is the circumference (2πr), while the displacement is zero because the object returns to the start.
  4. True. This inward force (centripetal force) is what continuously changes the object's direction, keeping it in a circle.
5

The Ferris Wheel

A Ferris wheel with a radius of 15 meters completes a full rotation in 90 seconds. How fast is a passenger riding at the very edge moving?

Step 1: Identify the given values.
  • Radius (r) = 15 m.
  • Time Period (T) = 90 s.
Step 2: Use the formula for speed in UCM.

v = 2πr / T

Step 3: Calculate the speed. (Use π ≈ 3.14)

v = (2 × 3.14 × 15 m) / 90 s

v = 94.2 m / 90 s

v ≈ 1.05 m/s

The passenger is moving at a speed of approximately 1.05 m/s.

6

Working Backwards

A cyclist is riding on a circular velodrome with a radius of 25 meters. If her constant speed is measured to be 10 m/s, how long does it take her to complete one full lap?

Step 1: Start with the speed formula and rearrange it to solve for Time (T).

Original formula: v = 2πr / T

Rearranged formula: T = 2πr / v

Step 2: List the known values.
  • Radius (r) = 25 m.
  • Speed (v) = 10 m/s.
Step 3: Calculate the time period. (Use π ≈ 3.14)

T = (2 × 3.14 × 25 m) / 10 m/s

T = 157 m / 10 m/s

T = 15.7 s

It takes the cyclist 15.7 seconds to complete one lap.
intros:
Lesson 14: Introduction to Uniform Circular Motion

Motion isn't always in a straight line. Let's explore the fascinating physics of moving in circles. Choose an intro below to start your discovery!

The Merry-Go-Round Ride

Ever felt pushed outwards on a merry-go-round, even when its speed is steady? Why does this happen?

When you're on a merry-go-round, your speed (like 5 km/h) might stay the same, but your direction is constantly changing. One moment you're moving north, the next you're moving east, then south, and so on. In physics, velocity is speed *plus* direction. Since your velocity is always changing, you are technically accelerating!

This acceleration is always pointed towards the center of the circle, and it's what you feel as a force pushing you. Your body wants to go in a straight line, but the merry-go-round keeps pulling you in, forcing you to turn.

"Constant speed but changing direction is the secret recipe for circular motion!"

The Tetherball Game

What keeps a tetherball from flying away in a straight line after you hit it?

The string is the hero here! An object in motion, like the tetherball, wants to travel in a perfectly straight line. This property is called inertia. However, the string won't let it. It constantly pulls the ball inward, towards the pole.

This continuous inward pull is a force that forces the ball to change its direction at every single moment, bending its straight-line path into a circle. If the string were to suddenly snap, the ball would instantly fly off in a straight line from wherever it was at that moment. The inward pull is what causes the circular motion.

"An inward pull for an outward curve."

The Cornering Race Car

Why do F1 cars need special tires and wings to go around corners so fast? It's not just about speed!

Think about driving a car. To go straight, you do nothing with the steering wheel. To turn, you must actively turn the wheel. That act of turning applies a force to the car through the tires, changing its direction. Even if your speedometer reading is constant, the fact that you are changing direction means you are accelerating.

For a race car on a curve, the force that makes it turn comes from the friction between its tires and the road. The special tires and aerodynamic wings are designed to maximize this turning force. Without enough force pointing towards the center of the curve, the car would fail to turn and would skid straight off the track!

"Turning is accelerating, even when your speedometer is steady."

The Earth and Moon Dance

The Moon has circled the Earth for billions of years. What invisible string keeps it from flying off into space?

The answer is gravity! The Earth's gravitational pull acts like a giant, invisible cosmic string. The Moon is always trying to travel in a straight line, but the Earth is constantly pulling it inward. This continuous pull from Earth's gravity bends the Moon's path into a near-perfect circle (an orbit).

So, the Moon is in a state of continuous free-fall around the Earth. It's constantly falling towards our planet, but it's also moving sideways so fast that it keeps "missing" it. This perfect balance between its forward motion (inertia) and the sideways pull of gravity (force) is what we call uniform circular motion on a cosmic scale.

"Gravity: Nature's string, keeping worlds in a cosmic dance."

The Spinning Bucket Trick

If you swing a bucket of water over your head, why doesn't the water fall out?

It's all about inertia! The water, just like any other object, wants to travel in a straight line. As you swing the bucket, your arm is constantly pulling it (and the water) inward, forcing it into a circular path. At the very top of the swing, the water is still trying to move "straight" (which is horizontally at that point). This tendency to move straight, its inertia, is stronger than the downward pull of gravity for that split second.

The water pushes against the bottom of the bucket, which is what keeps it from falling on your head. If you were to let go of the bucket at any point, it would fly off in a straight line tangent to the circle at the exact point of release. This proves that an inward force is required to maintain circular motion.

"An object in motion stays in a straight line... unless a force makes it turn."
summary:
Lesson 14 Summary

Uniform Circular Motion

This final lesson explores motion in a circle at a constant speed. It introduces the surprising fact that even with constant speed, this type of motion is always accelerating.

What is Uniform Circular Motion (UCM)?

It is the motion of an object travelling at a constant (uniform) speed along a circular path.

  • ➤
    Key Feature 1: Speed is constant.
  • ➤
    Key Feature 2: Velocity is NOT constant because the direction is continuously changing.

The Most Important Concept: UCM is Accelerated Motion

Because the direction of velocity is always changing, an object in UCM is always accelerating. This acceleration is called centripetal acceleration and it always points towards the center of the circle.

Velocity vs. Acceleration

  • ➤
    Velocity's Direction: Always tangent to the circle (touches the circle at one point and is perpendicular to the radius).
  • ➤
    Acceleration's Direction: Always points towards the center of the circle.

Calculating the Speed

To find the speed of an object in UCM, you divide the total distance of one circle (circumference) by the time it takes to complete it (time period).

v = 2πr / T

v = speed

r = radius of the circle

T = Time Period (time for one revolution)

π ≈ 3.14 or 22/7

Exam Quick Facts

  • Key Contradiction: Constant speed, but not constant velocity.
  • UCM is a type of accelerated motion.
  • If the string breaks or force is removed, the object flies off in a straight line tangent to the circle.
  • Formula to remember: v = 2πr / T.
